title: 道德經
source: Chinese Text Project (ctext.org) - James Legge translation

passages.zh: 人之生也柔弱，其死也堅強。
passages.en: (A warning against (trusting in) strength) Man at his birth is supple and weak; at his death, firm and strong.

passages.zh: 萬物草木之生也柔脆，其死也枯槁。
passages.en: (So it is with) all things. Trees and plants, in their early growth, are soft and brittle; at their death, dry and withered.

passages.zh: 故堅強者死之徒，柔弱者生之徒。
passages.en: Thus it is that firmness and strength are the concomitants of death; softness and weakness, the concomitants of life.

passages.zh: 是以兵強則不勝，木強則共。
passages.en: Hence he who (relies on) the strength of his forces does not conquer; and a tree which is strong will fill the out-stretched arms, (and thereby invites the feller.)
Therefore the place of what is firm and strong is below, and that of what is soft and weak is above.
